ngiemboon: Mbalam júʼ ntí gie Cʉ̀apʉ̀a tyě pɔ́ lénéŋ mbʉ́lè na pà Ésàlayɛ, à te gíŋe faʼa légʉa ńzɛ́te tsɔ́ nò gie á ge fó mbwó Ssé wɔ́, páʼ à kɔ̌ɔn ńzɔɔn ńgÿo na tsɔ́ mefʉ̀ʼ wɔ́, ńcʉ́ʼ sele nnɛ́ ńdíe pɔ́ shÿó nkùɔmekwaʼá.
en: Since Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord to bless Israel, he did not go to seek omens as on previous occasions, but turned   toward the wilderness.

ngiemboon: Ńgwɔ́ tà ḿbʉʼʉ nÿɔ́g, ńgyá jʉʼ gie pa Ésàlayɛ néŋe wó na mengẅɛ̀te mengẅɛ̀te, à Zẅìge Ssé pú ńjÿó yé,
en: When Balaam looked up and saw Israel encamped tribe by tribe, the Spirit of God   came on him,

ngiemboon: á lɔgɔ wɔɔn fǒloŋ, ńgɔɔn ngie:
en: and he proclaimed his poem:

ngiemboon: júʼu mmó gie n gɔɔn,
en: the oracle of one who hears the sayings of God,

ngiemboon: Aláʼa Ésàlayɛ, pi ée ngẅɛ̀ ndá Yakwɔ̂b,
en: How beautiful are your tents, Jacob,

ngiemboon: É vɔbɔ ssé páʼ tsìtsyɛ̀ gie á ne ńcwóŋo,
en: They stretch out like river valleys,

ngiemboon: Pɔ́ gíŋe ńgwɔ́ páʼ ntse gẅie
en: Water will flow from his buckets,

ngiemboon: E Ssé ka lɔg metʉ̀ mie ngwɔ́ tsɔ̌ nyìŋ le mǒ kuʼ, é mie ée páʼ mé nɔ̀ɔnnnɛ́, ńgÿo pɔ́ fó ngwòŋ Egíbtò ńkẅɛ,
en: God brought him out of Egypt;

ngiemboon: Pɔ́ gÿo pɔ́ páʼ mepúʼntʉ̀ la. Pɔ́ kẅíʼte ssé, ńtéŋe ńnuŋe…
en: He crouches, he lies down like a lion

ngiemboon: Mbalag pú ńgyáŋa lóŋ né Mbalam, tà ńtéʼe tepwó né yé, ńgɔɔn né yé ngie: «Mèŋ n ka lɔgɔ gú ńtóo jʉʼɔɔn légwɔ́ gie ɔ̀ ge néŋ ndòon twó megàŋmbù pɔ́ɔn, é pǐŋ ńgwɔ́ ngʉ̀a ntá páʼ ɔ̀ kě ḿpfɛte pɔ́ mbʉ́lè na pɔ́b!
en: Then Balak became furious with Balaam, struck his hands together, and said to him, “I summoned you to put a curse on my enemies, but instead, you have blessed them these three times.

ngiemboon: Afʉ̀ʼɔɔn la, fó lejʉ́ŋ mèŋ ńgʉa, piŋ nzèm lé mbʉ̀a gù. Mèŋ n da kaʼ páʼ n ge gÿo gÿo mekùʼ mú, tà e pú ńdúe, tá Cʉ̀apʉ̀a taté gú mǒ!»
en: Now go to your home! I said I would reward you richly,   but look, the Lord has denied you a reward.”

ngiemboon: Mbalam tsɔ́ʼɔ mbwó Mbalag ngie: «N da ké ńzɔɔn ńgɔɔn mbwó memántúm pie ɔ̀ la túm ngie:
en: Balaam answered Balak, “Didn’t I previously tell the messengers you sent me:

ngiemboon: Mbalag gwéʼe ḿbú ńná pɔ́ nkáb lâ tʉ̌ ngɔ̂ɔ gie áa nɔʼ yé tà ńdúe, mbà ńgwɔ́ ń de fʉa tsɔ́ na shwóŋè gie Cʉ̀apʉ̀a tsẅǐ wɔ́. Mèŋ n gɔɔn pɔ́ ndàʼ meshwóŋè mie Cʉ̀apʉ̀a tsẅǐi mbwó mèŋ.»
en: If Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I could not go against the Lord’s command, to do anything good or bad of my own will? I will say whatever the Lord says.

ngiemboon: Afʉ̀ʼɔɔn la, n ge gʉa kẅɛ́te pʉ̀a láʼ pɔ́ɔn. Táʼ, vɔg ńjúʼ, n ne kwoŋo lékága tuŋó jú, á na mmó gie pa Ésàlayɛ ge gÿo tsɔ́ lyɛ̌ʼ, é gÿo na pʉ̀a láʼ pú!
en: Now I am going back to my people, but first, let me warn you what these people will do to your people in the future.”

ngiemboon: Mbalam piŋ ńdɔgɔ wɔɔn fǒloŋ ńgɔɔn ngie:
en: Then he proclaimed his poem:

ngiemboon: Júʼu mmó gie mèŋ n gɔɔn,
en: the oracle of one who hears the sayings of God

ngiemboon: Mèŋ gyá mmó gie á ge gÿo tá tó,
en: I see him, but not now;

ngiemboon: À gíŋe ńkẅé ngwòŋ Seyî,
en: Edom will become a possession;

ngiemboon: Ngẅɛ̀ ndá Yakwɔ̂b ge kuʼu na megàŋmbù pé,
en: One who comes from Jacob will rule;

ngiemboon: Mbalam pɔ́ɔnte ńgyá pʉ̀a Amalɛg, ńgɔɔn né pɔ́b ngie:
en: Then Balaam saw Amalek and proclaimed his poem:

ngiemboon: Á gíŋe ńgyá pʉ̀a Keni, ńgɔɔn ngie: «Pi pʉ̀a Keni, pi ée láʼ pi, ńnéŋe na mejʉʼʉ mie mé la kwɛ́ tà é tʉte tà ńgwɔ́ mé le lwo ńtág wɔ́.
en: Next he saw the Kenites and proclaimed his poem:

ngiemboon: Tá á ké ńgwɔ́ pɛ́ʼɛ̀, emmɔ̌g ge gÿo sẅág membʉ̀a mí,
en: Kain will be destroyed

ngiemboon: Mbalam gíŋe ńkẅiʼi ńgɔɔn ngie:
en: Once more he proclaimed his poem:

ngiemboon: Epʉ̀a pie é ge fó ngwòŋ Shʉ́ʉpèle né memǎa mekanúʼ,
en: Ships will come from the coast of Kittim;

ngiemboon: Mbalam gɔɔn mɔɔn menò tà ńtsẅé jʉʼ, ńcʉ́me mánzsè, ńgwaa gʉa né yé láʼ, Mbalag lɔg wé nkwɔʼɔ́.
en: Balaam then arose and went back to his homeland, and Balak also went his way.
